title: Project Charter Development
description: Learn how the project charter formally authorizes the project and grants the PM authority to use organizational resources.
objectives: Understand the purpose and authority of the project charter as formal authorization
Identify the 7 essential components of a project charter
Recognize who creates the charter (sponsor) vs who uses it (PM)
Distinguish between charter (high-level authorization) and project management plan
Understand that work cannot formally begin without an approved charter

screens.headline: Riverside Plaza flagship: $1.2M investment, 6-month timeline. Carlos: 'Let's start planning!' Elena: 'Not without a charter.'
screens.body: Alex can't formally begin work, hire resources, or commit budget without an approved project charter. But Carlos keeps pushing: 'This paperwork slows us down!' Is he right?

dialogue.text: Without a charter, who authorizes Alex to spend $1.2M? What's the success criteria? What authority does Alex have? We need formal authorization—not enthusiasm.

screens.learningHook: The charter isn't bureaucracy—it's protection. Without it, the PM has no authority, no budget, no success criteria.

screens.title: Identify Missing Charter Components
screens.instructions: Elena presents a draft charter. Identify which critical components are MISSING.

scenarios.title: Draft Charter Review
description: - Project Title: Riverside Plaza Flagship Launch

questions.question: Which critical components are MISSING from this draft charter? (Select all that apply)

feedback.correct: Perfect! You identified all 5 missing components: Business Case, Objectives, Requirements, Success Criteria, Stakeholders. You correctly avoided D, F, H—those are created AFTER the charter during planning.
feedback.incorrect: Review: Charters include business case, objectives, high-level requirements, success criteria, stakeholders, budget summary, PM authority. They do NOT include detailed PM plans, WBS, or risk registers.

questions.question: Carlos says: 'Can't we skip the charter and just start planning?' How should Alex respond?

options.text: You're right. Let's skip the charter and start planning.
Let me ask Elena if we can start before charter approval.
The charter authorizes me to apply resources and spend budget. Without it, I have no authority to hire contractors, reserve your time, or commit costs.
PMI requires a charter, so we have to do it even if bureaucratic.

feedback.correct: Excellent! You explained that the charter authorizes Alex to use resources and commit budget. Without it, Alex has no authority—this protects both the project and the PM.
feedback.incorrect: The charter authorizes the PM to apply resources. Without it, the PM cannot hire contractors, commit budget, or make decisions. It's protection, not bureaucracy.

questions.question: Morgan asks: 'Should we add detailed menu specs and kitchen workflows to the charter?' What should Alex tell Morgan?

options.text: Yes, add all details to the charter.
No, the charter is high-level authorization. Detailed requirements go in the project management plan, created AFTER the charter.
Create two versions: high-level charter for executives, detailed charter for the team.
Add menu specs to charter, save workflows for later.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Charter is high-level authorization (2-5 pages). Detailed requirements, workflows, and schedules go in the PM plan (50-200+ pages) created after charter approval.
feedback.incorrect: Charter is high-level by design. Adding detailed specs creates a 100-page document executives won't read. Details belong in the PM plan, not the charter.

content.definition: The project charter is the document that formally authorizes the project and authorizes the PM to apply organizational resources to project activities.

keyPoints.explanation: Project sponsor, PMO, or portfolio steering committee (not the PM)
Project existence AND PM's authority to use resources
High-level (2-5 pages), not detailed execution plan

content.why: Protects the PM (authority), protects the project (success criteria), protects the organization (business case documentation)

components.name: Project Purpose / Business Case
components.example: Riverside Plaza targets 25-35 year-old professionals. Expected ROI: 18% annually.

components.name: Measurable Project Objectives
components.example: Open Oct 15, 2025. Achieve $80K monthly revenue within 3 months. Attain 4.5+ Yelp rating within 6 months.

components.name: High-Level Requirements
components.example: 2,200 sq ft restaurant, seat 120 customers, wood-fired pizza oven, 20 signature items

components.name: Summary Milestone Schedule
components.example: Lease signed Apr 15, Construction complete Aug 30, Grand opening Oct 15

components.name: PM Authority Level
components.description: WHO is PM and WHAT authority
components.example: PM: Alex Chen. Authority: Approve expenses up to $25K, hire within headcount, make menu decisions within brand guidelines

components.name: Key Stakeholders
components.example: Elena (Sponsor), Mall Developer, Health Inspector, Investors, Carlos (Operations)

plan.example: 2,200 sq ft layout with 30 tables, kitchen workflow diagrams, staffing schedules, detailed WBS...

content.insight: Charter = WHAT and WHY at high level. Plan = HOW in detail.

content.scenario: Carlos: 'Skip the charter and start planning!'

why_wrong.reason: Alex has no authority without charter
why_wrong.example: Can't hire contractors, commit budget, or reserve Carlos's time
Open Nov 30 with $60K revenue—success or failure? Without objectives, it's unclear

why_wrong.reason: No business case = can't justify investment
why_wrong.example: Leadership can't evaluate if $1.2M is best use of funds

content.outcome: Carlos understands charter protects everyone and enables proper authorization

90-100.text: Excellent work. Now I can present this charter to the board for the $1.2M authorization. It has everything executives need at the right level of detail.

70-89.text: Good understanding, but review one component. Either you're missing a charter element or confusing charter with PM plan.

below-70.text: Revisit what a charter is (high-level authorization), who creates it (sponsor), and what belongs in it—NOT detailed plans.

screens.title: Charter or No Charter? You Decide
screens.context: You're a PM at a software company. Your director says: 'We need a mobile app for sales. Budget roughly $200K, timeline 8 months. Can you start assembling the team this week?'

questions.question: Can you do these WITHOUT an approved charter? Swipe RIGHT (✅) if YES, LEFT (❌) if NO.

cards.explanation: Charter authorizes PM to apply organizational resources
No authority to commit funds without charter

cards.statement: Help the director draft the charter
cards.explanation: PM can ASSIST in charter creation

questions.question: Select the 5 components the director must include in the charter before you can start work.

feedback.correct: Perfect! You identified the 5 essential charter components and avoided detailed planning documents.
feedback.incorrect: Review: Charter includes business case, objectives, high-level requirements, PM authority, stakeholders. It does NOT include detailed schedules, WBS, or risk registers.

screens.title: Key Takeaways
screens.summary: The project charter formally authorizes the project and grants the PM authority to apply organizational resources. It's created by the sponsor during Initiating, contains 7 essential components at a high level, and must be approved before work begins.
takeaways: Charter authorizes the project and the PM—without it, PM has no authority
Created by sponsor (not PM)—PM can assist but sponsor must authorize
High-level authorization (2-5 pages)—not detailed like PM Plan (50-200+ pages)
7 essential components: Business case, objectives, requirements, milestones, budget, PM authority, stakeholders
Created during Initiating, before Planning—must be approved first
Protects PM (authority defined), project (success criteria clear), organization (business case documented)
Charter = WHAT and WHY. PM Plan = HOW (detailed)

characterClosing.text: I wanted to skip the charter and jump into planning. But Elena was right: without it, Alex has no authority to even ask for my time. The charter sets us up for success by defining what 'success' means.

nextLesson.title: Project Management Plan
nextLesson.teaser: You've authorized the project with a charter—now create the detailed roadmap that integrates all subsidiary plans into one cohesive PM plan.
